senses.de: Evidence that shows something is true or right
senses.ex: The lawyers did not have enough proof to win the case.

Tips.title: Legal Context
Tips.description: Used in legal situations to show evidence is strong enough to support a case.
Tips.example: Without solid proof, the judge dismissed the charges.

Tips.title: Need for Precision
Tips.description: Proof must be clear and direct, leaving no room for doubt or interpretation.
Tips.example: Scientists require conclusive proof before declaring a new discovery.

Tips.title: Collocations Matter
Tips.description: Certain phrases naturally pair with 'proof', emphasizing the need for evidence.
Tips.example: After the trial, she demanded proof of innocence.

senses.de: Resistant to a particular kind of damage or harm
senses.ex: The material is water-proof which makes it great for outdoor use.

Tips.title: Describing Durability
Tips.description: Highlights an item's resistance to specific damage like water, fire, or bullets.
Tips.example: He wore a bullet-proof vest to the operation.

Tips.title: Quality Assurance
Tips.description: Implies a product meets high standards of protection in its category.
Tips.example: This case is shock-proof, protecting your phone from falls.

Tips.title: Hyphenation Varies
Tips.description: Sometimes written as 'proof', 'proofed', or hyphenated, depending on usage.
Tips.example: My jacket is waterproof without the hyphen.

senses.ex: In mathematics, you have to show a proof for your answer.

Tips.title: Academic Evidence
Tips.description: In scholarly contexts, it means a logical argument that confirms a theorem or idea.
Tips.example: Her paper provided a rigorous proof of the theorem.

Tips.title: Math Specific
Tips.description: Used in mathematics to denote a step-by-step explanation.
Tips.example: I couldn't solve the problem until I reviewed the proof.

senses.de: To make something resistant to damage or harm
senses.ex: They proofed the papers against water damage.
This whiskey is 80 proof, it's quite strong.

Tips.title: Alcohol Content
Tips.description: Indicates the strength of alcohol using a specific scale in the US.
Tips.example: That bourbon is 90 proof, meaning it's quite potent.

Tips.title: Cultural Usage
Tips.description: The term is mainly used in the United States, not worldwide.
Tips.example: In Europe, they use percentage to show alcohol content, not proof.

senses.ex: You need to proof the dough for two hours before baking.

Tips.title: Baking Process
Tips.description: Refers to the important step in baking where dough is allowed to expand.
Tips.example: Proof the dough in a warm, moist environment for best results.

Tips.title: Time-sensitive
Tips.description: Duration of proofing can affect the texture and taste of baked goods.
Tips.example: If you proof the dough too long, it may become too airy.

Authenticate.wordDefinition:
Authenticate means to verify that something is real, true or genuine. For example, when you are logging into your social media account, you may be asked to authenticate your identity by entering a password or a code that is sent to your phone.

In simple terms, authentication ensures that you are who you claim to be.

In summary, authentication is used to verify identity or genuineness of something, while proof is used to validate a claim or statement by providing evidence.

Confirmation.wordDefinition:
Confirmation is when something is verified or agreed upon, often by a person or group.

In simpler terms, confirmation is a process of agreeing or verifying, while proof is evidence that supports or proves something to be true.

Corroborate.wordDefinition:
Corroborate means to confirm or support a statement or theory with additional evidence or testimony.

For example, a witness who saw a crime and then another witness who saw the same crime and tells the same story, the second witness would be said to have corroborated the first witness's account.

In simpler terms, corroborate is used to strengthen a belief or theory while proof is used to confirm something as true with absolute certainty.

Demonstration.wordDefinition:
Demonstration refers to showing or illustrating how something works or is done.

Demonstration is more applicable in situations where the goal is to teach or enlighten others, while proof is more applicable in situations where the goal is to establish the truth or validity of a claim.

Evidence.wordDefinition:
Evidence refers to information or facts that support an idea or claim.

It can be used in different situations, such as a court case where the prosecution presents evidence to prove the defendant's guilt.

Proof refers to evidence that conclusively establishes a fact or confirms a belief.

Evidence is used to support a claim, while proof is used to definitively confirm a claim.

Substantiate.wordDefinition:
Substantiate means to provide support or evidence for a claim or statement, without necessarily proving it definitively.

It is often used in more casual or informal contexts, and can imply a lower standard of certainty. For example, a student might need to substantiate a point they are making in a classroom discussion by citing relevant sources or examples.

Proof implies a higher standard of certainty and is typically used in more formal or rigorous contexts, while substantiate implies a lower standard of certainty and is often used in more casual or everyday settings.

Testimony.wordDefinition:
Testimony refers to statements or declarations made by a witness or an expert in a legal or formal setting. For example, in a court of law, witnesses are asked to give testimony about what they saw or heard in relation to a crime or event.

Testimony is often associated with personal observation or experience.

Proof is about demonstrating the truth of something through evidence, while testimony is about providing a first-hand account or information from a person who witnessed or experienced something.

Verification.wordDefinition:
Verification is the process of checking whether something is true or correct.

The main difference between the two words is that proof is used to convince others that something is true, while verification is used to confirm that something is true.

Proof is more about providing evidence, while verification is more about testing and checking.

quotes.Text: It is proof of a base and low mind for one to wish to think with the masses or majority, merely because the majority is the majority. Truth does not change because it is, or is not, believed by a majority of the people.
quotes.Title: Italian Philosopher
quotes.Name: Giordano Bruno

quotes.Text: I am falsely accused, without proof, of using my position for personal profit. Many who accuse me have lifestyles and spending habits that make them walking proofs of that crime.
quotes.Title: Filipino Statesman
quotes.Name: Gloria Macapagal Arroyo

quotes.Text: In matters of truth the fact that you don't want to publish something is, nine times out of ten, a proof that you ought to publish it.
quotes.Title: English Writer
quotes.Name: Gilbert K. Chesterton

quotes.Text: I remember the time I was kidnapped and they sent a piece of my finger to my father. He said he wanted more proof.
quotes.Title: American Comedian
quotes.Name: Rodney Dangerfield

quotes.Text: Seoul is ready to share with the world proof that local actions can achieve global vision.
quotes.Title: South Korean Politician
quotes.Name: Park Won-soon

quotes.Text: I'm living proof that whatever happens to you in life, you can turn base metal into gold.
quotes.Title: British Writer
quotes.Name: Lady Colin Campbell

quotes.Text: You can't tell me that dreams don't come true. My life is proof that they do.
quotes.Title: American Musician
quotes.Name: Fantasia Barrino

quotes.Text: I'm living proof that you can create your own life.
quotes.Title: American Celebrity
quotes.Name: Kim Zolciak-Biermann

quotes.Text: Life begins at 40, and I'm living proof.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Mariska Hargitay

quotes.Text: Fermat said he had a proof.
quotes.Title: English Mathematician
quotes.Name: Andrew Wiles
